_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Comply with OSHA and AWWA standards. Provide SARA Title III reports to EMA, ADEM, & Dothan Fire Dept
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Installation of motion sensors in the chemical storage area and entrance road
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Simulated leak drills with the fire department
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: SCBAs, protective clothing, chlorine/sulfur dioxide alarms and regulators, vent fans
_prev_prog_2.Description: Little Choctawhatchee sewage treatment facility prevention program covers a possible leak in the process.  Seak alarms will detect and notify plant personnel.  Automatic and manual shutoffs, vent fans and SCBA units are to assist plant staff in mitigating minor leaks in the system. These controls are checked, tested, and replaced by the plant staff (daily/monthly) and/or the manufacturer representative (Bi-annually).  Vessel (major) leaks are reported to the Dothan Fire Department. Standard Operating Procedures, Maintenance schedules, and Training activities are in place.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental release probability is minimized through training for employees in safe handling of chlorine and sulfur dioxide one ton containers and the correct Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for connecting and disconnecting one ton containers from the process.  The WWT Division in conjunction with the Dothan Fire Department conducts annual chlorine/sulfur dioxide leak drill at one of the facilities.  This is a full scale drill simulation a cylinder rupture with injuries and simulation evacuation procedures.

The WWT Division has three wastewater treatment plants that store chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas in one ton containers used for disinfection on treated wastewater.  The quantities stored at each facility is as follows: Little Choctawhatchee-6,000 lbs. of chlorine gas and 6,000 lbs. of sulfur dioxide;  Beaver Creek-6,000 lbs. of chlorine gas and 6,000 lbs. of sulfur dioxide; Omussee Creek 10,000 lbs. of chlorine gas and 8,000 lbs. of sulfur dioxide.  The total amount stored at all of the wastewater treatment plants is 22,000 lbs. of chlorine and 20,000 lbs. of sulfur dioxide.

The worst case scenerio for all three wastewater treatment plants would result in a maximum threat zone for sulfur dioxide of 3.2 miles.  Based on the 2,000 cencus, this release will affect residential population of 6,400 from Little Choctawhatchee, 21,000 from Beaver Creek, and 5,200 from Omussee.

The alternate release scenario for sulfur dioxide will affect a residential population of 4,300 from Little Choctawhatchee, 14,000 from Beaver Creek, and 2,700 from Omussee within a 2.6 miles.  The alternate release scenario for chlorine will affect a residential population of 3,500 from Little Choctawhatchee, 12,500 from Beaver Creek, and 2,300 from Omussee Creek within 2.4 miles.

The WWT Division has complied with the OSHA PSM rule , although Alabama is not an OSHA state.  The WWT Division conduct training for all operators in SOP, safe handling, and emergency response procedures.  All sa

fety equipment is regularly inspected and calibrated.  Both training and inspections are documented.

The WWT Division has had no accidental releasees of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas in the last five years.

In the event of an accidental release, WWT plant personnel will notify the Dothan Fire Department by either radio or land line.  The Dothan Fire Department's hazardous material team will take charge of stopping or mitigating the release of gas.  The annual full accidental release drill allows all agencies (Fire, Police,WWT) to critque their performance for improvement.  The WWT Division simulates leak drills quarterly at each facility to ensure operators are trained in SOP for emergency response.

Perimeter motion sensors have been installed to detect unauthorized personnel entering the plant or the chemical storage area.

The WWT Division reveiws SOP, conduct hazard analysis, and performs an audit every three years in compliance with the OSHA PSM rule.
